text: BAKERSFIELD, Calif. (KBAK/KBFX) — While the news can often be full of crimes and scandals going on in the community, there are a few moments every year that restore your faith in humanity. Some of those moments came from the men and women in uniform this year. There were multiple moments throughout the year where they took time to save, help, and love on the community that they serve. But the first situation did not start out very good, but we promise. It has a good ending. In July, [a mobile home caught on fire in Arvin.](https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/video-arvin-officer-braves-flames-and-smoke-to-save-chained-dog-from-raging-mobile-home-fire-kern-county-arvin-police-department#) The family was able to escape safely but they left [ a dog chained up to the fence,](https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/video-arvin-officer-braves-flames-and-smoke-to-save-chained-dog-from-raging-mobile-home-fire-kern-county-arvin-police-department#) leaving a life-or-death situation for the pup. That's when [ Officer Adam Calderon](https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/heroic-arvin-police-officer-braves-flames-to-rescue-trapped-dog-feet-from-house-fire-bakersfield-kern-safety) jumped in to save the day. The tense moments caught on the officer’s body camera showed him struggling trying to get the dog free. "Come on doggy, I'm trying." And at moments, it looked like it would be impossible. "Please, I am trying to save you boy. Come on." [Officer Calderon told Eyewitness News,](https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/heroic-arvin-police-officer-braves-flames-to-rescue-trapped-dog-feet-from-house-fire-bakersfield-kern-safety) "When I was trying to shelter the dog, my back was burning, and I honestly thought I was going to give up. I was saying ‘Lord help me’ cause I honestly couldn’t do it." Eventually, he found some pruning shears. After trying to cut the chain for a few minutes, he was able to rescue the dog. PETA gave him the [ Compassionate Action Award.](https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/arvin-police-officers-heroic-rescue-of-chained-dog-from-burning-home-earns-peta-award-kern-county-arvin) Another moment of good caught during a very tense time was during a standoff in Oildale. This time the deputy took a moment during the chaos of the dangerous situation to hold and protect an [ innocent little girl as she was seen crossing the street riding her scooter to safety.](https://bakersfieldnow.com/newsletter-daily/kern-county-sheriffs-deputy-helps-girl-ride-scooter-amid-standoff-kcso-kern-county-sheriffs-office-bakersfield-oildale) They aren't the only department helping the younger generation. [CHP Buttonwillow Officer Pense helped deliver a baby on Taft Highway.](https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/highway-patrol-officers-turn-stork-for-a-day-deliver-baby-girl-on-taft-highway-california-highway-patrol-kern-county) After the hectic delivery, the officer even went and visited the [baby named Daleyza at her home a month later.](https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/chp-officer-pays-heartwarming-visit-to-the-baby-girl-he-helped-deliver-on-taft-highway-kern-county-bakersfield-california-highway-patrol-buttonwillow) The mom and baby are healthy. Moving on to perhaps one of the most talked about things in the history of our county, the lottery. A [winning lottery ticket was sold right here in Kern County.](https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/california-lottery-officials-speak-after-record-setting-powerball-ticket-sold-at-frazier-park-store-midway-market-liquors-kern-county-bakersfield-los-angeles) "Someone is waking up this morning with a billion-dollar piece of paper." The jackpot was the second largest in lottery history totaling over $1.7 billion. The ticket was sold at [ Midway Market and Liquor in Frazier Park.](https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/jackpot-jitters-local-liquor-store-lands-lottery-legend-status-after-selling-billion-dollar-ticket) Some may call it luck or fate but all we know is that person beat the 1 in 302,575,350 odds. That being said, no one has come forward to claim the prize, but the owners of the market were still given $1 million for being the lucky store. "Hopefully we can give back to the community, have a little party in the parking lot." One Bakersfield native, may not have won the lottery but was hoping to win some money when she appeared for the second time on Jeopardy. [Eesha Sohail](https://bakersfieldnow.com/search?find=Eesha%20Sohail) is a Stockdale High grad who went on Jeopardy as a contestant for their high school reunion episode. Unfortunately, she did not win, but she represented Kern County well in the game show competition. And speaking of competition, [ Bakersfield Christian alum Derek Carr and Liberty High alum Jordan Love ](https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/bakersfield-natives-derek-carr-and-jordan-love-set-for-nfl-face-off-a-tale-of-two-careers)faced off in a head-to-head in a friendly rivalry NFL game. The two played against each other on their professional teams: the New Orleans Saints and the Green Bay Packers. [Carr's family let us know what they wished was the outcome.](https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/derek-carrs-father-breaks-down-matchup-with-bako-qb-love) "I hope that Love has a good game but that the Saints win." That wish did not come true as Jordan Love’s team, the Packers, ultimately came out victorious. They were not the only athletes to make headlines in Kern County. Two athletes reached out to help a boy who was allegedly being bullied in Arvin. A video went viral on social media showing a group of [Arvin High School students shaving a boy’s head against his will.](https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/alleged-bullying-at-arvin-high-school-caught-on-video-khsd-responds) Micah Parsons from the Dallas Cowboys and Marcus Smart from the Memphis Grizzles both posted on social media saying they wanted to help the young boy and give him some fun merch. Marcus posted on X, formerly known as Twitter, saying, "Thank you everyone for the help! I have made contact. I wish everyone understand love is spread in multiple ways. Don't wait until we see pain and suffering. Let’s continue to make strides in protecting our youth!" There was another young kid from Kern County who got the support of a celebrity. [Delilah Loya](https://bakersfieldnow.com/news/local/local-girl-fighting-cancer-receives-special-visit-from-plain-white-ts-singer) has been battling cancer for four years. She has had 30 rounds of chemo and radiation. "They told us she had stage four neuroblastoma cancer and it's 95 percent of her bone marrow and she said specifically she is going to have to fight for her life." Which is why she needed a little encouragement and help from one of her favorite celebrities. Delilah was named after the song "Hey There Delilah." and Tom Higgenson, the lead singer of the Plain White T's who sang that song gave her a little surprise. Which did exactly what it was intended to do, put a smile on her face. "I was just like oh my gosh, and I just did this face."
